ckanr vignette
==============

## Install

Stable version from CRAN


```r
install.packages("ckanr")
```

Development version from GitHub


```r
devtools::install_github("ropensci/ckanr")
```


```r
library("ckanr")
```

Note: the default base CKAN URL is set to [http://data.techno-science.ca/](http://data.techno-science.ca/). You can change this using `ckanr_setup()`, or change the URL using the `url` 
parameter in each function call.

To set one or both, run:


```r
# restores default CKAN url to http://data.techno-science.ca/
ckanr_setup() 
# Just set url
ckanr_setup(url = "http://data.techno-science.ca/")
# set url and key
ckanr_setup(url = "http://data.techno-science.ca/", key = "my-ckan-api-key")
```

## ckanr's dplyr interface
`ckanr` implements a `dplyr` SQL interface to CKAN's datastore. 
You can access any resource in the datastore directly using only the CKAN
resource ID.

The path from a CSV (or XLS) file to a table in a CKAN datastore is:

* A [tidy](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tidyr/vignettes/tidy-data.html) 
  CSV file is uploaded as file resource to a CKAN dataset.
* CKAN's datapusher (if enabled) attempts to parse the CSV and upload it into
  its own table in the datastore. The datastore has a database separate to CKAN.
* Depending on the CSV's size, the upload to the datastore can take seconds to
  minutes.
* Once the CSV is uploaded sucessfully to the datastore, CKAN will show a green
  "Data API" button on the resource's page.
* The table in the datastore is named after the resource ID (an MD5 hash).

The following two lines will configure a given CKAN instance as source, 
and read all records in one resource datastore table into a tibble.
Note, `as_tibble` forces the lazy `tbl` query to run and actually retrieve all
records.

```{r eval=FALSE}
ckan <- ckanr::src_ckan("https://my.ckan.org/")
dplyr::tbl(src = ckan$con, from = "my-ckan-resource-id") %>% tibble::as_tibble(.)
```

As also explained in `??src_ckan`, you can list all available resources in the
datastore:

```{r eval=FALSE}
dplyr::db_list_tables(ckan$con)
```

If your resource ID is not in this list, make sure it uploaded to the datastore 
correctly.

The above example retrieves all records at once. In contrast, dplyr's use of SQL
allows server-side filtering and any data manipulation possible in SQL.

There are many good tutorials about using dplyr's SQL interface, e.g.
[datacarpentry.org](http://www.datacarpentry.org/R-ecology-lesson/05-r-and-databases.html).
